Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sw1218 hello, i have my results of the biopsy. my report says 6 of the 8 cores taken are gleason 7 prostate cancer. here's the rest of what was said and written. i down't know how to attach the pathology report for everyone to C. that's quite a bit to copy. i'm scared and sad. i don't know what to do. This letter is a follow-up to our telephone call today 2/28/2019. As I discussed with you, your pathology results for your prostate biopsy indicates that SIX of your EIGHT sample cores were positive for prostatic adenocarcinoma (prostate cancer). The severity of prostate cancer is graded on a scale from 2 to 10 called the Gleason Score. Prostate cancer with Gleason Scores 7 through 10 are considered ones in which medical intervention is required. SIX of your prostate samples from the three lesions previously identified by MRI prostate had Gleason Scores of 7 or greater. Medical intervention is typically radiation therapy or radical prostatectomy (surgical removal of the entire prostate). However, these are not the only treatment options available to patients. Your earlier MRI of prostate indicated that there was no evidence of spread of cancer beyond the prostate to the lymph nodes or pelvic bones. This is great news! You have informed me that you will contact me early the week of March 4th 2019 to inform me who you would like to meet with for the Multidisciplinary Prostate Cancer Clinic appointment. I can schedule you with Dr. Sanda, Dr. Patteras or Dr. Filson. The purpose of the Multidisciplinary Prostate Cancer Clinic:  To inform patient of all available treatment choices  To help patient evaluate all the treatment options  To answer questions about available therapies  To help patient with choosing a treatment option What we recommend between now and your appointment is to do your own research on the following topics. Prostate cancer, radiation therapy for prostate cancer, prostatectomy, recovery time after prostatectomy, and Gleason Scores. This research will help you formulate questions to ask the doctor that you meet with at the follow-up. We encourage you to bring either a spouse, fiancee, family member or friend to your follow-up appointment. This will allow you to focus your attention on the discussion with the doctor while your guest can capture notes and provide emotional support. A copy of your pathology report for prostate biopsy is attached. Listed is a link that may be helpful in your research about prostate cancer: https://www.cancer.org/content/dam/C...ic/8796.00.pdf Please let me know if you have any questions in regard to your results. Sincerely, Jan Johnson, NP-C Hi Sw1218, many of us had gone through what you experienced. I can understand the emotional and mental duress. I'm sure many of the brothers here can attest to that. I too was a G7 (4+3) after TRUS biopsy, which turned out 3+4 in post RP. have completed 1 round of RT as well. Do stay strong and work with your doctors to decide the best possible treatment. Your partner is really important in providing you the solid home support you need, so hold fast to each other. All the best!
Posts.Signature: Age at diagnosis: 58 in 2018 Pre op PSA: Total PSA 7.52 ug/L, Free PSA 1.42 ug/L, p2PSA 29.64 ng/L, phi 57 Biopsy: 5 of 13 cores, G7 (4+3) No perineural or lymphovascular invasion seen Tc-99m HDP whole body bone scan: Jan 2018 No definite scan evidence of bone metastases MRI of pelvis and prostate: Jan 2018 Prostatic capsule remains intact, No pelvic lymphadenopathy seen, no suspicious bony lesions identified. Da Vinci RP: Feb 2018 Surgical Pathological Exam G(3+4) = 7 grade group 2, tumor 10% of total volume Positive margin: Right Posterior Mid, Focal, 2mm, Highest grade at margin G(3+3) = 6 Pathological stage pT3aNx PSA post-surgery 3 mths PSA 0.038 ug/L, 6 mths PSA 0.122 ug/L 1 round RT, 3 mths post RT PSA 0.03 ug/L

Posts.Title: My Biopsy Results Are In

Posts.Content: Hi all I'm new to this fantastic forum. I'll quickly summarise my background: Age: 58 PSA Pre-Operation: Dec 2017 PSA: Total PSA 7.52 ug/L, Free PSA 1.42 ug/L, p2PSA 29.64 ng/L, phi 57 Biopsy: 13 cores Dec 2017 Right lobe: base x 2, mid x 2, apex x 2 RB: G(4+3) full core length, G4 for 70% of tumor present RM: G(3+4) 30% of core, G4 for 30% of tumor present. Separate detached core G(3+4) 10% of core, with G4 for 30% of tumor seen. RA: G(4+3) for 60% of core, G4 for 60% of tumor seen. Separate detached core G(4+3) 90% of core, with G4 for 60% tumor seen. Adenocarcinoma No perineural or lymphovascular invasion seen Left lobe: base x 3, mid x 2, apex x 2 Benign Tc-99m HDP whole body bone scan: Jan 2018 No definite scan evidence of bone metastases MRI of pelvis and prostate: Jan 2018 Prostatic capsule remains intact Seminal vesicles are unremarkable No pelvic lymphadenopathy seen, no suspicious bony lesions identified. Da Vinci RP: Feb 2018 Surgical Pathological Exam G(3+4) = 7 grade group 2, tumor 10% of total volume Positive margin: Right Posterior Mid, Focal. Summed length of positive margin 2mm Highest grade at margin G(3+3) = 6 Pathological stage pT3aNx PSA post-surgery Apr 2018 PSA 0.038 ug/L Jul 2018 PSA 0.122 ug/L Based on the PSA reading and path report my RO is recommending RT for 6.5 wks (33 daily sessions except sat and sun). should I go for it or wait for a 3rd reading. Due to the nature of my work, 33 sessions can be disruptive and I have 2 clear windows that have minimal disruption: one in 3 wks time and the other Mar Apr 2019. Can you good folks pls advise me? TIA Tony
Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: Hi guys I did 2 tests with diff labs 2 days apart: 0.11 and 0.122. I am inclined to start soonest though but wanted an independent opinion. RO did say to try SRT first rather than HT.

Posts.Content: Hi Dave tks for the reply. yup there was a 2mm margin continence is good and I'm also peeing a lot as I drink abt 1.5 to 2L water a day. I'm kinda struggling a bit about the RT, logic tells me that I should start it though... :/

Posts.Content: great to hear that!! Originally Posted by leach234 Just received my 7 month PSA results. <0.02. Lowest Quest Diagnosis can detect. Not bad for a Gleason 8 Ductal Adenocarcinoma with focal margin!

Adenocarcinoma No perineural or lymphovascular invasion seen Left lobe: base x 3, mid x 2, apex x 2 Benign Tc-99m HDP whole body bone scan: Jan 2018 No definite scan evidence of bone metastases MRI of pelvis and prostate: Jan 2018 Prostatic capsule remains intact Seminal vesicles are unremarkable No pelvic lymphadenopathy seen, no suspicious bony lesions identified. Da Vinci RP: Feb 2018 Surgical Pathological Exam G(3+4) = 7 grade group 2, tumor 10% of total volume Positive margin: Right Posterior Mid, Focal. Summed length of positive margin 2mm Highest grade at margin G(3+3) = 6 Pathological stage pT3aNx PSA post-surgery Apr 2018 PSA 0.038 ug/L Jul 2018 PSA 0.122 ug/L Based on the PSA reading and path report my RO is recommending RT for 6.5 wks (33 daily sessions except sat and sun). should I go for it or wait for a 3rd reading. Due to the nature of my work, 33 sessions can be disruptive and I have 2 clear windows that have minimal disruption: one in 3 wks time and the other Mar Apr 2019. Can you good folks pls advise me? TIA Tony
Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: Hi Dave tks for the reply. yup there was a 2mm margin continence is good and I'm also peeing a lot as I drink abt 1.5 to 2L water a day. I'm kinda struggling a bit about the RT, logic tells me that I should start it though... :/
Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: Hi guys I did 2 tests with diff labs 2 days apart: 0.11 and 0.122. I am inclined to start soonest though but wanted an independent opinion. RO did say to try SRT first rather than HT.
